H0.text: Ideal conditions allow populations to grow exponentially.

H1.text: Pleasant conditions are those under which populations can grow exponentially.

H2.text: Useful conditions are those under which populations can grow exponentially.

H3.text: Lush conditions are those under which populations can grow exponentially.

A4.text: Initial exponential growth often does not last forever, instead slowing down eventually due to upper limits caused by external factors and turning into logistic growth.

A5.text: The number of microorganisms in a culture will increase exponentially until an essential nutrient is exhausted, so there is no more of that nutrient for more organisms to grow.

A6.text: Most populations do not grow exponentially, rather they follow a logistic model.

A7.text: Once the population has reached its carrying capacity, it will stabilize and the exponential curve will level off towards the carrying capacity.

A8.text: Exponential growth takes on the assumption that there is unlimited resources and no predation.

A9.text: These birds experienced exponential growth from the years 1975-1994 and grew about 55 times their population size from 1975.

A10.text: Exponential Population Growth of Monk Parakeets in the United States
